body: Also, not cache the seldomly requested ones.

I'm interested in working on this, and curious as to the motivation for this enhancement. Are there any specific operational issues the service is currently experiencing, or that you foresee it experiencing, if this enhancement is not implemented and the service keeps loading all models into a dict?

> I'm interested in working on this

@mvkski better to start with an issue with the good-first-bug label: https://github.com/mozilla/bugbug/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3Agood-first-bug.
You can still work on this if you want of course, but it might not be as easy as those.
NOTE: The only thing missing here is removing items from the cache after two hours.

> , and curious as to the motivation for this enhancement. Are there any specific operational issues the service is currently experiencing, or that you foresee it experiencing, if this enhancement is not implemented and the service keeps loading all models into a dict?

The reason behind this change is reducing memory usage of the HTTP service. It is currently high, and will be too high if we add more models.

@marco-c Thanks! I'd like to take a crack at this task for now, but will take a step back if it doesn't work out. I think I have a handle on what needs to be done here

 If I understand correctly, the dict on the following line:
https://github.com/mozilla/bugbug/blob/22b27b97b0a7ec4d84c8b374cb56c2c5f3f9d734/http_service/bugbug_http/models.py#L41
Needs to be switched out from a dict to a cache supporting a TTL. Currently I think https://cachetools.readthedocs.io/en/stable/#cachetools.TTLCache with a TTL parameter of two hours would do the trick, but am still researching (not sure if this TTL will refresh when a model is retrieved). 

I had more questions on what problems specifically you might expect to see due to high memory usage, but I think I'll refrain from taking up too much of your attention with them right now(I might feel emboldened to ask if a PR of mine for this issue is accepted 🙂)

>  Needs to be switched out from a dict to a cache supporting a TTL. Currently I think https://cachetools.readthedocs.io/en/stable/#cachetools.TTLCache with a TTL parameter of two hours would do the trick, but am still researching (not sure if this TTL will refresh when a model is retrieved).

I've looked at cachetools, but it looks like the cache is only cleaned up when you actually access it, so it doesn't help a lot by itself in reducing memory usage. We could set up a background thread which periodically performs the cleanup.

> I had more questions on what problems specifically you might expect to see due to high memory usage, but I think I'll refrain from taking up too much of your attention with them right now(I might feel emboldened to ask if a PR of mine for this issue is accepted slightly_smiling_face)

Simply: running out of available memory :)
On a Heroku `Standard 2x` worker we only have 1 GB available, so we have to use it carefully.

> I've looked at cachetools, but it looks like the cache is only cleaned up when you actually access it, so it doesn't help a lot by itself in reducing memory usage. We could set up a background thread which periodically performs the cleanup.
 
Thanks for catching that! If we have a cleanup thread run only once every two hours it seems to me like it would solve the problem.  If I understand correctly, the problematic nature of the [global interpreter lock](https://wiki.python.org/moin/GlobalInterpreterLock) applies to this situation, but since the cleanup thread would only need to run very infrequently negative performance effects on inference should be negligible. 
 
> Simply: running out of available memory :)
> On a Heroku `Standard 2x` worker we only have 1 GB available, so we have to use it carefully.

That makes a lot of sense! Thanks - its very satisfying to work on something when you have full visibility into why its needed 😃.

> Thanks for catching that! If we have a cleanup thread run only once every two hours it seems to me like it would solve the problem. If I understand correctly, the problematic nature of the global interpreter lock applies to this situation, but since the cleanup thread would only need to run very infrequently negative performance effects on inference should be negligible.

Indeed!

Also, If we're going to be writing our own cleanup thread, it seems like we may as well go the distance and implement our own TTL cache from scratch rather than take on an external dependancy with more features than we need.

It shouldn't be too much extra code to do so (I'm estimating 20-50 lines?). Having a small amount of extra code in the project seems to me like a fair price to pay for the cost of reducing the chance we end up with [dependancy hell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dependency_hell) related problems.

It sounds good to me, we already partially have it now (see https://github.com/mozilla/bugbug/blob/b72e96b269478cdce2b6aceef4beb190238c0eea/http_service/bugbug_http/models.py#L40 and https://github.com/mozilla/bugbug/blob/b72e96b269478cdce2b6aceef4beb190238c0eea/http_service/bugbug_http/models.py#L67-L71), so we just need the cleanup thread to go through the entries and remove stale ones.

issue.title: Ttlcache

repository.name: bugbug
repository.description: Platform for Machine Learning projects on Software Engineering

issue.body:
PR for https://github.com/mozilla/bugbug/issues/1342

I added unit tests and integration tests for the proposed cache, but haven't yet been able to get the http service running locally on my machine so have yet to verify end to end. I'll be asking questions on how to do so in matrix, since that seems like the most appropriate channel for the topic.

body: Created PR for the issue. Wrote unit tests and an integration test for the cache, but haven't verified end to end yet due to having issues launching http_service locally. Asking in matrix how to launch service.
